title.narrative: Responsible Business for Sustainable Development- DIHR/GRI work

description.narrative:
Insatsen baseras på en förändringsteori utformad gemensamt av GRI och DIHR och ger en gemensam ram och mål för både enskilda projektförslag som har lämnats in av de två organisationerna till Sida.
Det övergripande målet för GRI- och DIHR-programmets ramverk "Hållbart företagande för hållbar utveckling" är att ett ansvarsfullt företagande stödjer hållbar utveckling i dess ekonomiska, sociala och miljömässiga dimensioner. För att uppnå detta kommer programmet att stimulera företag och statliga aktörer att vidta effektiva åtgärder för att uppnå ansvarsfullt företagande på tre nivåer. I en ömsesidigt beroende värld där naturresurser utarmas och ojämlikheten växer är det avgörande att ta hänsyn till miljö-, samhälls- och styrningsaspekterna av den ekonomiska tillväxten. Med andra ord, utveckling som främjas måste vara socialt, miljömässigt och ekonomiskt hållbar och fast förankrad i mänskliga rättigheter.
För det första syftar programmet till att öka företagens, små, medelstora och stora företag, öppenhet och transparens genom förbättrad hållbarhetsredovisning i linje med ramarna för hållbar utveckling och mänskliga rättigheter. För det andra är programmets syfte att lyfta fram ansvarsfullt företagande som facilitator för hållbar utveckling genom att möjliggöra evidensbaserad, kritisk dialog och skapa verktyg för att stimulera staten och näringslivets aktörer, inklusive investerare, att fatta beslut som uppmuntrar ansvarsfullt uppförande. För det tredje syftar programmet till att stärka genomförandet av ramverk för ansvarsfullt företagande på nationell nivå i linje med nationella strategier för hållbar utveckling.
De viktigaste områden av programmet är: 1) ökat utnyttjande av publika hållbarhetsdata inom ramen för affärsmetoder 2) internationella och nationella hållbarhetspolicies och strategier som baseras på evidensbaserade dialoger 3) handlingsplaner kring ansvarsfullt företagande utvecklas i linje med nationella strategier för hållbar utveckling.
Dessutom kommer DIHR att fokusera på ytterligare ett kompletterande projekt som fokuserar på människorättsfrågor som är länkade till frågan om hållbara hav och kommer att ta itu med frågor om mänskliga rättigheter som gäller maritimsektorn och kustområdena i utvalda länder såväl som på regional och global nivå. Arbetet i specifika länder kommer att bidra till att identifiera nyckelfrågor, bygga kapacitet och utveckla metoder och verktyg för att ta itu med dessa frågor på nationell nivå. Samtidigt utgör de en grund för peer learning och politisk dialog inom regionala och internationella fora.
Målen för det speciella projektet kring hållbara hav kan sammanfattas enligt följande:
(1) mänskliga rättighetseffekterna av fiske och vattenbrukssektorer dokumenteras och åtgärdas i multistakeholder dialoger om hållbar utveckling, ansvarsfullt företagande och mänskliga rättigheter i Bangladesh och Chile
(2) god praxis, verktyg och vägledning utvecklas för att identifiera, adressera och övervaka de människorättsliga konsekvenser och effekter av fiskeri- och vattenbrukssektorn för att sedan ligga till grund för dialog mellan viktiga aktörer inom områdena hållbar utveckling, ansvarsfullt företagande och mänskliga rättigheter på en global skala
Sida har valt att göra en gemensam bedömning av GRI och DIHR i ett försök att ytterligare förstärka det redan pågående samarbetet mellan de två organisationerna och skapa en plattform för att skapa bättre effektivitet i Sidas insatser inom hållbart företagande. Sida har ett tydligt fokus inom hållbart företagande att fördjupa förståelsen för hållbarhet till att även omfatta frågor direkt kopplade till fattigdom, informalitet och integration av små och medelstora företag i hållbarhetsmetoder. Mänskliga rättigheter är viktiga komponenter i detta synsätt och därför är samarbetet mellan GRI och DIHR viktigt och ansträngningar att bistå båda organisationerna att gå vidare inom respektive område viktigt. Det bör dock betonas att det är främst en fråga om att ge stöd till de enskilda organisationerna och deras egna program och samtidigt fördjupa samarbetet mellan dem för att ytterligare fördjupa strategierna för hållbart företagande och företagens ansvaret som utvecklingsaktörer.

The initiative is based on a theory of change designed jointly by GRI and the DIHR and provides a common framework and objectives for both individual project proposals have been submitted by the two organizations to Sida. The overall objective of GRI and DIHR-application framework "sustainable enterprise for sustainable development" is that responsible entrepreneurship supports sustainable development in its economic, social and environmental dimensions. To achieve this, the programme will stimulate business and governmental actors to take effective action to achieve responsible business at three levels. In an interdependent world where natural resources depletion and inequality grows, it is crucial to take account of environmental, social and governance aspects of economic growth. In other words, development that promoted must be socially, environmentally and economically sustainable and firmly anchored in human rights. First, the programme seeks to increase business, small, medium and large companies, openness and transparency through improved sustainability reporting in line with the framework for sustainable development and human rights. Secondly, the programme's aim to promote responsible entrepreneurship as a facilitator for sustainable development by enabling evidence-based, critical dialogue and create tools to stimulate government and industry stakeholders, including investors, to make decisions that encourage responsible behaviour. Thirdly, it seeks to strengthen the implementation of the framework for corporate responsibility at the national level in line with national strategies for sustainable development. The main areas of application are: 1) increased utilization of public stability data as part of business practices 2) international and national sustainability policies and strategies based on evidence-based dialogues 3) action plans regarding responsible business develops in line with national strategies for sustainable development. Furthermore, DIHR to focus on an additional complementary project that focus on human rights issues linked to the issue of sustainable seas and will deal with human rights issues relating to the maritime sector and coastal areas in selected countries as well as at the regional and global levels. Work in specific countries will help to identify key issues, build capacity and develop methods and tools to deal with these issues on a national level. At the same time, they constitute a basis for peer learning and policy dialogue in regional and international fora.
The objectives of the special project on sustainable seas can be summarized as follows: (1) the human rights impacts of the fisheries and aquaculture sectors are documented and addressed in multi-stakeholder dialogues on sustainable development, responsible business and human rights (2), good practices, tools and guidance developed to identify, address and monitor the human rights implications and effects of the fisheries and aquaculture sector then lie the basis for dialogue between key actors in the areas of sustainable development, corporate responsibility and human rights on a global scale has chosen to make a joint assessment by GRI and the DIHR in an effort to further strengthen the already ongoing cooperation between the two organizations and create a platform for creating greater efficiency in Sida's efforts in sustainable enterprise. sIDA has a clear focus within sustainable business to deepen the understanding of sustainability to include questions directly linked to poverty, informality and the integration of small and medium-sized enterprises in sustainability practices. Human rights are key components of this approach and therefore is the collaboration between the GRI and the DIHR is important and efforts to assist both organizations to progress in each area is important. However, it should be emphasised that it is mainly a question of giving support to the individual organisations and their own programs and at the same time strengthen the cooperation between them to deepen further strategies for sustainability and corporate responsibility development actors.

description.narrative: The impact of the COVID 19 pandemic has severely impacted the implementation of both components in the collaboration with DIHR. Despite of it, a number of achievements have been achieved in 2020. Namely they are as follows reflected under the respective components: Responsible Business [NORM/GLOB] The draft universal Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) standards published for consultation in 2020 increasingly reflect human rights and align with critical business and human rights (BHR) frameworks. Given the extensive application of these standards globally and their impact on other reporting frameworks this alignment is crucial to ensure that they support respect of human rights by reporting organisations. In 2020, the DIHR increased efforts in the area of sustainability reporting and has been in close coordination with GRI feeding into policy debates on non-financial reporting and mandatory human rights due diligence legislation. The DIHR-GRI collaboration on standard-setting was noted as a very positive aspect of this programme by the mid-term review. [NORM/GLOB] In 2020, the DIHR was appointed to the European Union (EU) Sustainable Finance Platform, an expert body tasked with advising the EU Commission on fully developing the EU taxonomy for environmentally sustainable economic activities as well as potentially extending it to other dimensions of sustainability including social sustainability. Given the challenges associated with meaningfully developing the social and human rights dimensions of non-financial reporting and sustainability taxonomies, promoting sound human rights-based approaches in such fora is critical. Contributing to such initiatives allows the DIHR to draw on invaluable lessons learned gained on non-financial reporting to date, including through the GRI collaboration. [NORM/GLOB/INST/NAT] 2020 saw an increased focus of the DIHR’s engagement in the area of technology and human rights. Significant developments in this regard included the finalisation of the National Action Plans on Business and Human Rights (NAPs) Toolkit tech supplement, as well as the publication of a briefing on human rights responsibilities for technology giants. Notably, these deliverables were directly connected to stakeholder dialogue on the human rights dimensions of technology development, prompting subsequent engagement with the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR), the Council of Ethics of the Swedish Pension Funds and other actors working on human rights respect and protection in the development of digital technologies. Importantly, learning in this space has taken place not only in the form of research and tools development but also in the form of practical engagement at country level. [NORM/GLOB] The finalisation and launch of the Public Procurement Toolkit. The toolkit provides practical and concrete approaches for those with responsibilities for procurement in public agencies. While highlighted by the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights (UNGPs) as a specific area for attention, very few actors have picked up on this topic to work towards human rights protection in public procurement. Given the vast volume of public procurement globally, however, this marks a key area for real impact, if such practices are brought in line with human rights expectations. [NAT/INST] In light of the mid-term review’s reflections regarding the DIHR’s focus on NAPs vis-à-vis other national-level processes promoting RBC, this engagement area is further worth noting. While the piloting of the toolkit with national-level procurement agencies was hampered by the pandemic, with public procurement agencies at the coal face of dealing with medical and other necessary supplies during the pandemic, conversations resumed at the end of the year to undertake a first pilot with the Kenyan Department of Justice, and other relevant actors, in 2021. [NORM/GLOB] Further orientating the programme towards gender in BHR, 2020 included several key steps to integrate gender within various areas of the programme. Activities included, for example, conducting a gender review of the NAPs website and draft indicators of the future digital data collection tool, developing thinking on the gender dimensions of public procurement and the digital transition, and prompting partners to further reflect on the gender dimensions of BHR in joint activities. In addition, the gender learning exchanges hosted by the DIHR with the purpose of building exchange between practitioners and researchers working on gender and BHR were very positively received by participating stakeholders and prompted immediate follow-up engagements in 2021. The programme’s increased attention to gender also continues to foster developments within the DIHR’s International Area more broadly, with the DIHR’s Gender Reference Group activities being consolidated into a 2021-2022 workplan and gender now being explicitly mentioned in the DIHR’s 2021-2024 strategy. [NAT/INST] The most significant impact of Covid-19 on the programme’s activities was on country-level work and engagements. In Kenya, for example, a case study on the NAP was successfully completed. The case study examines both the strengths and weaknesses of the process, ultimately building the case for the importance of multi-stakeholder engagement and leadership to make such processes meaningful, including through targeted stakeholder and rights-holder participation, including in different regional locations within countries, to avoid being a ‘capital city/ elite’ policy exercise. The potential for NHRIs to play a valuable role, due to their independence and human rights knowledge, also presents interesting learning for other countries. [NAT/INST] In July 2020 the Zambian Human Rights Commission completed a baseline study on the implementation of the UNGPs in the agricultural and extractive industries sectors, which presents an important ‘test case’ for how NHRIs might incorporate Pillar II analyses in NAP processes that have primarily focused on Pillar I and III of the UNGPs. The launch and publication of the baseline study has been delayed because of the Covid-19 pandemic and is expected to proceed in 2021. Strengthening NHRI capacity to monitor business activities has been expressed as a key demand from many of DIHR’s NHRI partners and collaborators and therefore identified as a key work area for 2021, for which the Zambian Commission’s Pillar II baseline can provide important insights and learning. [NAT/INST] Despite the fact that the results of the 2019 elections in Ukraine meant that the civil servants working on BHR were replaced, and that building relationships with new staff and keeping BHR on the agenda required significant efforts, it is noteworthy that the new National Strategy on Human Rights included a chapter on BHR. The DIHR also supported the Parliamentary Ombudsperson to develop a study on ‘Business impacts on human rights in times of Covid-19’ and to present it at the first Regional Forum on BHR in Eastern Europe. Sustainable Oceans: [NAT/INST] The Sector Wide Impact Assessments (SWIA) with implementing partners in Chile and Bangladesh constitute the foundation for most of the outputs and outcomes achieved. In spite of the challenges partners faced in light of Covid-19, both partners managed to finalise draft versions of the SWIAs that will be finally published and disseminated in 2021. [NAT/INST] The Bangladeshi partners responded to contextualizing the SWIA process to Covid-19, by starting a Rapid Situation Analysis that compared the socio-economic situation in the fishing communities. The data showed that the lockdown and subsequent 65-ay Ban on fishing, made that the vast majority of fishers had to take loans to cover their basic needs. The studies resulted with roundtable discussions with the Ministry of Fisheries and Livestock, FAO, trade unions amongst others. The focus centred around the need to secure social protection measures for fishers during restrictions on fishing and the need to invest in alternative livelihood developments in communities. As a result of the work conducted by DIHR and its partners resulted in local authorities to amend the official list of fishers. The list is important as is the official Fisher ID card, which gives access to social security allowances in times of fishing bans and crisis. [NORM] At structural level it led for the Govenment in Bangladesh's official Voluntary National Review Report on progress against the 2030 Agenda, it also highlighted the need to compensate poor fisheren with social protection allowances during fishing ban periods. [NAT] In the African Region, two studies and videos in Senegal and Ghana respectively, were finalised despite initial delays caused by the uncertainty of the effect of the pandemic on the continent. A third study has been delayed due to Covid-19 related restrictions on movement in Ghana, which impeded on the planned field work, but this has been moved to 2021 under a no-cost extension and will still be done. [NAT/INST] The pandemic also led to unexpected, but positive outcomes. Not least in Bangladesh, where DIHR partners contextualized the SWIA process to the Covid-19 situation and conducted a Rapid Situation Analysis that compared the socio-economic situation in the fishing communities as of April-May 2020 with the 2019 SWIA data from the same areas, collected at the same time of the year. The analysis resulted in the publication of a report that was launched at a virtual Roundtable Discussion and discussed by several high-ranking government and state authority representatives participated. [NAT/INST] Another positive result of the adaptation and mitigation measures undertaken in the light of the pandemic was the global move to virtual rather than physical events, which has had unforeseen benefits in terms of participation. For example, two virtual events organized by the INDH in Chile to present the draft SWIA report allowed for approximately thirty attendees from across Chile to attend each event, which would not have been possible in the case of a physical event. It also allowed for ease in collaboration and joint facilitation of the events between DIHR and partners and can be a lesson for the future on how to organize events across regions, without having to travel extensively. [GLOB/NORM] Similarly, at the global level, the project’s planned outreach and advocacy activities initially stalled due to the spread of the pandemic and the many cancellations and postponements of planned key events. However, as the world quickly adapted, and many events moved online, it allowed for project staff to participate in both planned and unplanned events to promote the key messages on salient human rights issues, including the UN Regional Forum on Business and Human Rights for the LAC region, the Danish Initiative for Ethical Trading, the UN Global Compact Sustainable Ocean Business Action Network. In some cases, as with INGO Too Big to Ignore on the World Oceans Day 2020, shifting to a virtual space even allowed for DIHR to co-organise parts of the events and taking a leading role in presenting and putting human rights at the centre stage. This was partly due to the cost-effectiveness of the online format, which has meant that the project team’s involvement in the organisation, arrangements and participation of these events presented less of a strain on project resources, both in terms of funding and, more importantly, in terms of time.
